direction.raw_text: Leo Tolstoy (80), sits writing on his lapboard. He is quite simply the greatest living writer in the world. His devotion to pacifism, his rejection of the trappings of Orthodoxy in favor of a simple Christian lifestyle convince many to regard him as a living saint. With him are his much younger wife, the COUNTESS SOFYA, favorite daughter SASHA, and his personal physician DUSHAN MAKOVITSKY. Sasha and Dushan write in their diaries. Sofya looks from one to the next a little impatient. The train begins to slow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are we slowing down? No one responds. Slower. Slower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're stopping. Why are we stopping?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, mother.    No idea. Tolstoy look up from his work, asks a passing conductor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, why has the train stopped?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the crowd, ma'm, the people. They're blocking the track. In the distance we can here voices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long live Tolstoy! Long live the old warrior!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But if they block the track, the train can't go...YOU HAVE TO MAKE THEM MOVE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The conductor shrugs, walks away. She goes to the window to investigate. A crowd of a hundred peasants, students surround the engine, block the track. They carry a huge cloth banner honoring Tolstoy. We can hear voices chanting "Tolstoy. Tolstoy. Tolstoy", voices crying "You are the truth." "You are the hope of the Russian people."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, they won't move. We are gonna die here. Leo, Leo, go and say something to them. It's the only way we are gonna get out of here. The chanting grows in intensity. Tolstoy gets to his feet, walks to the window, shows himself to the crowd. A great shout goes up. Tolstoy lifts his hand for silence. Gradually, it comes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have seen your banner. And I ve heard what you say. You think I m the hope of Russia, do you? Well, that s not true. You are the hope of Russia. The hope of all the world. You say, you want a new way to live? Well, you are not gonna find it making a fuss over me. So, I suggest that you get on with your work and let a poor old men get on with his. The cries begin. "Clear the tracks. Let them pass. Let them go." Tolstoy closes the door and waves to the crowd as the train pulls away. 3   EXT. COUNTRYSIDE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know who that is? That is the greatest man in the world. The train pulls away into the distance. TITLE OVER BLACK: SPRING 1910 4   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. DAWN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Muzhiks (peasants) gather wood, carry water to the house. A cart arrives loaded down with mail bags. 5    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: On the chanting crowd now as the train pulls away. We focus on a handsome young man, a little stiff maybe, a little intellectual. This is VALENTIN FEDOROVITCH BULGAKOV. He can't contain his enthusiasm. Over the noise of the train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The ancestral home of the Tolstoy family in the first budding of spring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A handsome room, walls covered with generations of family photographs. Religious icons are given pride of place, a testament, not to piety, but to an ingrained social conservatism, a certain position in the world. Countess Sofya mumbles her morning prayers before a make shift altar. Wiping away tears, she leaves the room. 5A   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY/STAIR. DAY.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sofya walks down the stairs and through the entry passed an old servant asleep in a chair. She continues to the basement. 6    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. TOLSTOY'S BEDROOM/STUDY. DAY.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tolstoy has moved himself out of the refined upper floors into a simple vaulted room he uses as both bedroom and study. The walls are bare except for a portrait of his daughter. The furniture is simple, some of it hand made: a small bed against the wall, a little writing desk in one corner stacked with books, littered with papers, more mail, opened and unopened. Pairs of rude homemade shoes line a work bench. Tolstoy sleeps in his bed. Though it's late March and still cold, the window is open. Sofya closes it. She stands very still, watching Tolstoy sleep. Sitting on the bed, she gently touches his hand, whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling. She lies next to him, something girlish, hopeful in her face, as if waiting for him to wake up and adore her, but he sleeps on. She carefully takes his arm, positions it under her neck, and rolling toward him, wraps it around her. The image of love's intimacy, of wedded bliss. His hand slips off her shoulder, once, twice. She moves awkwardly to replace it. He moves a little toward her. She kisses his neck, his cheek. We don't know if he's awake, but even this shadow of intimacy penetrates her soul. 7    OMITTED                                                       7 4. 8   INT. MOSCOW. STUDY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But sex... You are twenty three. Not an easy age for abstinence, is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tolstoy does not approve of sexual relations. I know this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He despises them, in fact... Chertkov reaches for a small tin of moustache wax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to belabor the point, but I arranged for a manservant last year who proceeded to ruin two housemaids just like that. He was very upset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This would not be a problem. I'm celibate. I'm also a strict vegetarian. Chertkov nods his approval, begins to worry his moustache.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I've heard many good things about you. I've even read what you`ve written. So has he. Valentin's face flushes with pride. Chertkov steals a glance at his reflection in the glass bookcase. One side of his moustache droops a little. He tugs awkwardly at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dear boy, if you were to become Tolstoy's private secretary, you would be given a great gift. You'll be with him every day, eat together, walk in the forest by his side. It's difficult to contain himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Believe me, since becoming a Tolstoyan, I have become so eager to learn, so comitted to discussing ideas, improving my very soul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Well, we have a lot to do if we are to get his work to the people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We? They both laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, we. If we can encourage the spread of passive resistance...just think of it Valentin   thousands of ordinary Russians casting off centuries of spiritual and political oppression-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the name of truth and freedom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Truth and freedom, yes but still, my boy, there are so many enemies-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enemies? Chertkov walks to the window, signals Valentin to follow him. He points to TWO MEN IN PLAINCLOTHES standing in the street below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Czar's police...You'll be followed when you leave here...and the church will stop at nothing to bring him back into the fold. His children can't be trusted... only Sasha... and then of course there is the Countess... (beat) Well, one doesn't like to come between married people whatever the circumstances, but her dogged attachment to private property, her public criticism of our movement... (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beat) The point is, he needs a man of your intellectual gifts around him. Someone who can help him with the new work. Someone who understands his goals. Chertkov returns to the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And although they've allowed me to return to Russia, I can't see him. They keep me under house arrest... They might as well keep me in a cage. Clearly upset, Chertkov pauses to get control of himself. He picks up a package, hands it to Valentin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, I need you to put these letters directly into his hands. One can't be sure what gets through to him. Valentin looks at him, quizzical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya Andreyevna does not respect his privacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She wouldn't open his private correspondence... Chertkov raises an eyebrow. An ominous silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have another task for you, my dear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll keep a diary for me. He hands Valentin a notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need to know everything that goes on at Yasnaya Polyana. Let me know who visits the house, any talk of the copyright to his work, any contact with the church, what letters come and go. (beat) Anything Sofya Andreyevna says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's very, very dangerous. 9    EXT. MOSCOW. DOORWAY/STREET. EVENING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Godspeed, my boy. Valentin makes his way to the droshky that awaits him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And remember what I said. He turns back to the dark figure in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Write everything down! Go! 10   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. MORNING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 11 Where Tolstoy, awake and dressed, sits on his bed, pen in hand, writing in his diary. Dushan sits next to him, taking his pulse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing's working... Hand me my other boot, my friend, will you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me finish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't matter. If my heart had stopped beating, I'd still go riding today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your pulse is my responsibility... (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and if you must ride, I insist you wear a coat. Even the sun is cold today. He puts Tolstoy's arm down and hands him his riding boot. Sofya comes ranting into the room carrying several Russian and international dailies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is impossible! It really is! These people are parasites! Look... (reading) "Countess Tolstoy has become estranged from her husband. They barely speak." She throws the paper on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know who spreads all this rubbish.... She opens another paper, a French daily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'est la meme en France. They gossip about us in Paris... "They do not share a similar view of either religion or politics." Incroyable!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Peut-etre. You think that's inaccurate?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it's none of the world's business. She looks at Dushan who is transcribing every word into his diary. He does it with all the master's conversations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing? Don't do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Dushan Petrovich, you're scribbling again? Tolstoy moves with energy and purpose toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling, where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riding with Sasha. Don't expect us for lunch. Something strikes him. He walks to his desk, picks up his pen and quickly writes a sentence on a scrap of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leovochka, why do you insist on dressing like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like the man who looks after the sheep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not meant to offend you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it does offend me, because it offends reason. You're a Count, for God's sake. He puts his pen down, goes to her, kisses her gently on the forehead and leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh darling, I have something else to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I doubt it not, my dear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's forgotten his coat. He runs after him, tripping over the long fur garment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Count Tolstoy, you've forgotten your coat. Meanwhile Sofya notices a photographic portrait of Chertkov on the wall. She takes it down and tosses it in the corner. 12   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let him walk. Let him walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Count Tolstoy, you're no doubt distressed by the Czar's treatment of your secretary Nikolai Gusev ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These people are bandits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said, let him walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They come into my house and arrest a man whose only crime is to express a view of life saner than that which prevails.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So Gusev is innocent?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nods) Of course, I'm the guilty one. I reject the Orthodox church. I condemn the established order and I make no secret of it. A young peasant shouts from the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God bless you, Tolstoy. Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let him walk. Let him walk. (to Tolstoy) But you don't banish these people very much to your credit...I wish I had your largeness of spirit. A photographer's flash goes off. An old Muzhik touches Tolstoy's sleeve, as if expecting a miracle. Sasha, her father's soulmate, leads two horses toward them, her mount and her father's black gelding, Delire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sasha!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you ride this morning? A small crowd collects to watch father and daughter embrace, kiss. A WIDE SHOT of the riders- cutting around we are 13   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY/STAIR. CONTINUOUS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A handsome study in the Moscow townhouse of VLADIMIR GRIGOREVICH CHERTKOV, Tolstoy's most articulate and dedicated disciple. He's interviewing Tolstoy's newly appointed secretary, VALENTIN BULGAKOV, the young man we met near the train, who, at the mention of sex, blushes a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Chertkov kisses Valentin delicately on both cheeks and ushers him into the dying light.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . Black and white film of her being handed the newspapers at the step. She looks up at the camera, irritated by its presence. CUTTING OUT TO COLOR we see a cinematographer on the lawn cranking away at his camera. She goes into the house. 11   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. TOLSTOY'S BEDROOM/STUDY. MORNING.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As Tolstoy appears on the porch, we hear the WHIR of cameras. A crowd of photographers, film cameramen, journalists, and disciples try to catch a glimpse of the master. Dushan steps in front of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sofya watches her husband and daughter ride away. 14   EXT. RIVER VALLEY. DAY                                       14 A steam train snakes through a broad valley. 15   INT. TRAIN CARRIAGE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Telyatinki was created by Vladimir Grigorevich as a center for the movement. Just last week we had a visitor from India. We talked to the group about the healing properties of cobra venum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, goodness..It's a beautiful day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but we will pay for it. Sergeyenko, Chertkov's joyless secretary, and Valentin stand on a second storey porch looking out across the central lawn where a number of young Tolstoyans tend the garden, work to put up a chicken coop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The meeting room is behind us. This is the tool shed. The dormitory ahead. He points out a larger building across the way. 17   INT. TELYATINKI. SLEEPING AREA. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Telyatinki is a place of freedom. Nothing is forbidden here. Except everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Each man is alone with his conscience and his God. (beat) The kitchen is below. You'll be expected to assist with meals at least twice a week ...and to give a hand in the garden. We're all equals here, you know...as Tolstoy teaches us. They start up the stairs. INT. SLEEPING PORCH. TELYATINKI. DAY SERGEYENKO You are expected at Yasnaya Polyana in the morning, first thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I look forward to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... you're lucky....We're all envious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 18   INT. TELYATINKI. VALENTIN'S ROOM: NIGHT                      18 Small, sparse, perfect for the novice ascetic.   Valentin nods his approval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vladimir Grigorevich is anxious that you begin your reports as soon as possible. You have the notebook he gave you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You understand we must keep the existence of the diary a secret. Valentin smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just that...secrecy doesn't seem to me the essence of Tolstoy's thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you'll admit, you're no expert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I...I'll see you in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If we're spared. Sergeyenko leaves Valentin to his bare, little room. 19   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. MORNING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in. A lovely girl at his door. She's tall, twenties, high cheek bones, short blonde hair. This is MASHA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've brought you a glass of tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's very kind of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your first day. Enjoy it. She sits on the bed. He's a little taken aback, not used to this degree of familiarity. It makes no impression on Masha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You met Sergeyenko?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ad what do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He seems very sincere. Masha hands him his tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Why are you laughing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say that again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said he seems very... Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that what you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just arrived...What's your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha. But you should still say what you think. Not just about him. We all should.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for the tea. Their eyes meet, hold. Valentin's discomfort increases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow you can make your own. She walks to the door, turns to see him still watching her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a sorry old tight-assed stick in the mud...but yes, he's sincere. 21   EXT. ROAD TO YASNAYA POLYANA.   DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello...hello...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're the new secretary. He looks up to see Sasha examining him from the landing above.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa's out. You can wait in the library. Ivan will show you up. She disappears. He hears a door close. He notices a surly house servant, IVAN, who, inexplicably, leads a goat through the house. He points upstairs and walks away. 24   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad you're here. So glad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He tromps across the room, kisses the boy enthusiastically on both cheeks. Valentin is overcome by the great man's warmth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm... I'm... Here is- Valentin interrupts himself with a sneeze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God bless you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.     Sometimes I... Valentin pulls out a letter of introduction. Tolstoy takes it out and puts it down without a glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vladimir Grigorevich has already written about you at length. I need your help badly. The manifesto against the government is hard work. They commit their idiotic abuses faster than I can catalogue them...and the new book...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He told me about it...It's very exciting. Tolstoy nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've become convinced that all the world's religions have a single organizing principle. Can you guess what it is? Love! Love! Simple... Now, I want to talk about you. How are you? How was your journey? Come, sit down. Tolstoy sits on the old sofa. Valentin follows suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, I was born on this sofa... Valentin gets right back up. Tolstoy laughs, pats the sofa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit. Sit. Valentin sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Myself, my brother, my children, at least five or six of them, right here. (beat) Now, I've read your essays. How`s your work progressing? Valentin looks into the great man's kind old face. He tries to speak but he's overcome with emotion and begins to weep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My boy, what is it? (beat) I upset you in some way. Was it the sofa? It's only a sofa. Valentin shakes his head, smiling through his tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm very happy. You are very kind. I'm no one and you are... you are Leo Tolstoy and you ask me about my work. Tolstoy takes Valentin's hand, sits him back on sofa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You rest for a moment and I'll fetch you a glass of tea. Rest, because there's work for both of us together. He smiles and goes, leaving Valentin to contemplate his fortune. 25   OMITTED                                                       25 26   OMITTED                                                       26 27   OMITTED                                                       27 28   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These people have nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It really is the most extraordinary thing. Absolutely ignoring him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not for lack of land that the muzhiks live in poverty. They have no will power and they drink too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not suggesting they be given land. Private property is the root of the problem... We should be giving ours away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give it to whom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all ridiculous. You think that poverty makes the peasants somehow morally superior.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe that wealth corrupts us all, yes I do. A pause.   Valentin fills the silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a keystone of the movement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I know all about the movement. A pause. Valentin notices that people from the front lawn have moved up to watch all this. Life in the fishbowl, the Tolstoys seem neither to notice nor care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the peasants had money, they wouldn't surround themselves, as we do, with footmen costing ten rubles a month.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, they'd spend it on drink and whores.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin Fedorovich, do you think fifty years from now, people will eat while grown men walk around and wait on them hand and foot?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Valentin doesn't know what to say. A giggle from Dushan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, that's good...that's good. Dushan, having sat at table, tries surreptitiously to get down Tolstoy's words in the diary he holds below the table. Sofya flushes with anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think...(sneeze)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop scribbling! (points to her husband) You all think he's Christ, don't you? He thinks he's Christ. There is an awkward pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (flustered) I'm not...I don't believe Leo Nikolayevich is Christ. Christ is Christ but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe he's one of the prophets. God speaks through him. I recognize the cadence in his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is unbearable. No wonder I feel lonely. I'm surrounded by morrons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama, you're being ridiculous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I? I sit here and listen to this talk of love and God and equality, knowing full well that Count Generosity here is fully prepared to give away everything we have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (exhausted) You keep going on like that...Why do you think we should profit from the work I m doing which is only meant for the sake of the people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She turns to see Dushan scribbling again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !   STOP WRITING NOW! Valentin glances at Sasha, uncomfortable at these outbursts. A long pause. Dushan tries to relieve the tension.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In defense of my gift, let me demonstrate. It's quite remarkable, really. He gets up, places a record on the gramophone, needle on the record. What comes forth is not music, but Tolstoy's voice. It is a recording of a recent speech against capital punishment. His voice booms, tinny and distorted. Dushan walks to the machine, stares at it in awe. Valentin is completely caught up in the technology.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your voice. It's wonderful. They all listen for a moment, look to Tolstoy for a response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's tiresome. Another remarkable invention will supercede it. Valentin blushes and looks at the table. Dushan tries to hide his disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please excuse me. Tolstoy rises, leaves the table, walks out onto the lawn. Dushan gets up quickly, bumping the table as he goes. Tea spills. Valentin moves to wipe it up, sneezes, a barrage of irritable blessings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leo Nikolayevich is something of a Luddite, I fear. Sofya crosses to the machine, removes the record from the gramophone, replaces it with another Dushan has brought. Suddenly, the air is filled with   the final duet from Mozart's Il Nozze di Figaro. She   returns to her place. There is a long moment where all   take in the sublimity of it. Tolstoy walks slowly back to   the table. He stands completely still. Tears fill his   eyes and roll down his cheeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, that s better. That s nice. Very nice indeed. Sofya crosses to her husband, wipes the tears off his face. Valentin watches as they embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do your parents often speak to each other so...bluntly? 29   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. EVENING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother doesn't understand my father's goals, not since his work as a novelist became secondary.    His commitment to the spiritual life offends her. They've fought about it for years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure she means well. Sasha just looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your father is the greatest writer in the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite. A pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean to say, I feel privileged to be here. It's an... honor. Valentin feels himself slip further into mundanity. Sasha goes back to her letter.   Valentin SNEEZES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God Bless You. They read together for a moment.   He sneezes again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God bless you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Sometimes I sneeze when I'm nervous. She regards him like an animal in the zoo. Ivan appears at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It s a note, for him. He nods toward Valentin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, give it to him then. Valentin reads the note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It s from your mother. She wants to see me. As Valentin goes,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is looking for allies. Pay attention. This is war. 30   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SITTING ROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see a fine young man before me. Clear eyes. Nice features, rather handsome in a peculiar way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Countess...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call me Sofya Andreyevna. We don't stand on formality here, as you may have observed. (beat) Many young men ruin their looks by loose living. You're a real Tolstoyan, I can tell!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I admire your husband immensely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's excellent. He likes that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His ideas are beautiful...social justice...the idea...Don't you think? Sofya drains her tea cup, signals for more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's very grateful for the help you've been giving him. He told me so himself. I think it surprises him that a young man would be so diligent. When he was your age, he was whoring in the Caucasus. Valentin's eyes are wide. She nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wrote it all down. He even gave me a copy, so I could read all the details...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've read War and Peace?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Many times... twice. Sofya smiles at his honesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When he was writing it, long before Chertkov created that monstrosity at Telyatinki, before all this "new religion" and revolutionary nonsense... (beat) What do you think of Chertkov, by the way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's given me an extraordinary opportunity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you see what a fool he is, a self-serving puritanical idiot. I have to say, it's been extremely pleasant since they've locked him in his house. Sofya smiles. Valentin is nonplussed by her directness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When my husband was writing it, in the mid-sixties, he'd bring me pages to re-copy everyday. I was the only one who could read his handwriting. I could read his intentions, too. Afternoons, we'd drink tea and discuss changes. "Natasha wouldn't say that to Prince Andrey," or "Pierre's too simple here. He's not stupid." She smiles at the memory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I don't count anymore. Silence. She sips her tea. She glances out the door to see Sasha hovering nearby. Listening? Sasha walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must help me, Valentin Fedorovich. I want only what is best for my husband and my family. I could tolerate the situation if it only concerned me What I can not do is sit back while they steal my children's inheritance. Do you know I was the only person. I could understand his intention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe anyone wants to do that. Sofya gives him a condescending smile. She produces a package from the table beside her, hands it to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a little gift for you He opens it, extracts a small leather bound book. He stares at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a diary. (beat) Everyone should always keep a diary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a very popular activity around your husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're teasing me, but I trust you'll write the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That may not be so easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nonsense. You've been listening to your friends at Telyatinki... (beat) Write what you see. That's always the place to begin. (slowly) What. You. See. Valentin fingers the package, stifles a sneeze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More tea? 31   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. DAY                                31 Valentin rides into the compound. A number of the disciples are outside working. There is the ringing of metal on wood. He looks for the source. As the way clears a little, he sees Masha chopping away with an axe. He stops his horse to watch her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're finished for the day?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't need me this afternoon. He gets down off his horse. Masha continues to chop. He picks up an axe, holds it awkwardly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leo Nikolayevich disapproves of women doing physical labor. (beat) Don't you find that reactionary?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I find it sweet. I find you reactionary. She laughs. Valentin picks up a log, sets it on end and begins to chop. He doesn't do it well. Masha smiles at his struggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He admires you, I believe. What's she saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergeyenko told me. He's miserable about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tolstoy's kind to everyone. The log is stuck to the blade of his axe. He's really struggling now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you talk about when you're with him? (beat) Why are you blushing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We talk about me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wants to know everything about me, my parents, my relations with women, my experience of god - He looks up to see Masha smiling at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what relations are these? Valentin blushes, goes back to trying to chopping. Almost immediately the log becomes stuck to the blade of the axe. He bangs it, bangs it trying to free it. He glances up to see her still looking at him. He pounds again and again. She stops, reaches for his axe, touching him as she does. She lifts the big axe, log and all, above her head, bringing it down hard. The log splits. She hands the axe to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had a lover before I came here... headmaster of a school where I taught. He was married - happily married. It was difficult. We could make love only at school. This is somehow more than Valentin had bargained for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the gymnasium, after the girls had gone. There were straw mats on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He looks away to hide his confusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have I upset you? He looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No...I appreciate your frankness
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you disapprove of me. I see it in your eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't. Not at all...I think sexual activity...how men and women combine their physical parts is completely neutral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to you. You're a prig. Just like Sergeyenko. Why else would they have hired you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not fair
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care if it's fair. It's true...neutral...my God...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going. He puts down the axe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do as you like. She goes back to chopping. We track in front of him as he walks toward the house. The chopping stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin Fedorovich. He stops, relieved and turns to face her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You forgot your horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. You know, I think that I... never mind. He hesitates for a moment, then starts toward her. Her back is to him. She begins to chop again. The color rises in his face as he tries to salvage a little dignity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He grabs the reins and starts again toward the buildings, trips in a ditch, almost falls flat. Red faced, he rights himself. The chopping behind him remains constant. Sergeyenko watches him from the porch. 32    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY                           32 CLOSE on the CABLE MACHINE.    A message coming through. 32A   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY WAY/STAIR. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya walks into the house with another stack of mail. Sasha comes piling down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's papa? Without waiting for the answer, Sasha races past her and out the door 33    OMITTED                                                      33 34    EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ZASYEKA WOODS. DAY                     34 Valentin and Tolstoy walk together in the woods. .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't write. I was distracted I think...I had a dream last night, about a Tartar girl I knew in the war.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A girl who died?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no...A girl I had sexual intercourse with... Sometimes we did it twice a day. Valentin sneezes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God bless...I've never forgotten our time together, the position of our bodies, the taste of her...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shouldn't torture yourself. It was a long time ago. Tolstoy laughs out loud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Torture? You are a virgin, aren't you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I try to...you know, to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To be what, a good Tolstoyan? Tolstoy smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, I myself am not a very good Tolstoyan. You should think twice about asking my advice about anything... Torture... (he laughs)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kalya, her name was...She's an old woman now, white hair, old body like me. She'd hardly remember my name, I suspect. She may even be dead. (beat) Do you think that meant something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean that little romance. Was there some meaning to it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It s interesting. I think you would say..I mean, I ve read where you say that the physical body isn t real. That it s all an illusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I say lots of things. What do you say? What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I don t know. Leo Nikoleyevich smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don t know, either. He inhales deeply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smell that...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lilac? He looks up as he hears Sasha off screen. "Papa. Papa."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Precisely. It's lilac. The smell's stronger when the sun goes down. He presses Valentin's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've enjoyed myself, my boy. (shouting for Sasha)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin in his buttoned up suit looks a little out of place in the overcrowded third class carriage. He writes in the diary given him by Chertkov. He glances up to see, on the bench across, a young mother taking out her breast to nurse her baby. He blushes, doesn't know where to look. An old peasant catches his eye, winks at him, laughs. 16   EXT. TELYATINKI. DUSK.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seven miles from Tolstoy's estate, this is Telyatinki, a communal center created by Chertkov dedicated to the study and practice of Tolstoyism.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They enter the building.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The sun rising. Already, disciples are at work the gardens. 20   INT. TELYATINKI. VALENTIN'S ROOM. MORNING.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin sleeps in his tiny room. A knock on the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A modest horse drawn cart. Valentin sits beside the driver, contemplates the birch trees that line the road, the long shadows they cast. Above, crows make lazy circles in the sky. 22   OMITTED                                                       22 23   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY WAY/STAIRS. DAY.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin stands in the entry way, waiting.   He looks lost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alone now among Tolstoy's books, Valentin makes his way slowly to a writing table, the holy of holies, on which War and Peace and Anna Karenina were written. He runs his hand along the old wood top. Emboldened by a backward glance, he sits in Tolstoy's chair. Before him are stacks of letters, pens and pencils, a pot of India ink. There's a notebook lying open. He leans forward to read it. A noise in the hall stops him. Tolstoy enters from the dining room, red cheeked, beard dripping wet, the energy of a man ten years younger than he is. Valentin stands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sofya, Sasha, Valentin, ANDREY, Tolstoy's son, and Tolstoy all clustered around a table taking tea. Dushan stands near the group fiddling with a gramophone that sits on a small table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Across from Tolstoy's writing desk is Sasha's world, a makeshift office lined with more bookcases where she does her work, sending cables, editing manuscripts, answering endless stacks of mail. Valentin sits near her, learning the ropes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sofya is settled on a divan in a small room off the dining room. Valentin sits beside her holding a glass of tea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . As he starts in the direction of her voice. Sasha appears in the clearing, telegram in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's free. He's free...He's coming back Smash cut to 35   EXT. RAILWAY. COUNTRYSIDE. DAY                              35 A train roars past camera, shaking the world. 36   OMITTED                                                     36 37   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY                          37 Chertkov climbs down from his droshky. Suddenly, Tolstoy is there. Valentin watches them embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dear, dear man. Tears run down his old cheeks. They embrace again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll try again to convince your father to change his will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 38   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY/STAIRS. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To give the copyright as "a gift to humanity."...the reptile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa's not in his right mind. He can't defend himself against these thieves. (beat) My tooth is killing me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a fine son, darling. None of this make believe chastity and made up religion. I wish all my children had turned out like you. Andrey's finger in his mouth, massages the offending molar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A man'th responthibility ith to hith family. From her POV, we see the two men walk away together arm in arm, talking animatedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chertkov's notions of virtuous behavior are calculated to destroy me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To dethtroy uth all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is nothing more pathetic than impoverished aristocrats. She walks out of the room. 39   EXT. GROUNDS. YASNAYA POLYANA. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vladimir Grigorevich, what a surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya Andreyevna, I'm happy to see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Valentin watches her match him smile for smile.                    *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm happy to make you happy...always. 40   OMITTED                                                       40 41   EXT. ROAD TO TELYATINKI. DAY                                  41 Valentin and Chertkov sit together in the droshky, an awkward silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad to have a moment alone with you, Valentin. How do you think you're getting on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a little nervous) I hope my work is pleasing to Leo Nikolayevich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. He seems satisfied and that's good. The reports I've received from you however... There seems to be some confusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You send me never ending commentary on Tolstoy's writing. That's all very interesting but not very useful. I need to know what goes on with Sofya Andreyevna. You must see by now she's committed to undermining her husband's best intentions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not quite so obvious to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because she is duplicitous. You are very bright. Too bright to let her into you. Chertkov fixes the boy with his intense gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You value our work?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ideals we share?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I'm here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, of course it is. (beat) Do you think the Countess suspects something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I think the Countess is very suspicios by nature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don t think she likes you very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does she say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It s a tone I ve picked up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We simply want to distribute Tolstoy's work to the widest audience possible. She just has no understanding what it is we are trying to do. There s nothing in it for any of us but a real chance to increase the world s happiness. He takes Valentin's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can only be of limited help to the master if I don't know what's going on. Any effort she makes to shore up control of the copyright, I must know. The survival of our movement depends on it. Remember who your friends are. What you've come here to do. Chertkov turns away to watch the countryside. Valentin stares straight ahead, his nose twitches slightly. 42   OMITTED                                                    42 34. 43   OMITTED                                                      43 44   OMITTED                                                      44 45   OMITTED                                                      45 46   OMITTED                                                      46 47   INT. TELYATINKI. VALENTIN'S ROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello... Hello? After a moment, it opens a crack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha? She is there. She puts two fingers to her lips and walks toward him. She carries a candle which reveals her short hair, her lovely eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha. She says nothing, simply crawls into bed, positions her knees on either side of him. She leans forward and kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ssshh. She begins to move against him. Their faces touch. She doesn't kiss him, but he can feel her breath. She sits up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Move the book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your book. It's true. Valentin still clutches the diary to his chest. He puts it aside. Masha, then, pulls her nightdress over head, exposing her small breasts, her flat stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She reaches under the sheets, curls her fingers around him. He flinches at the pleasure of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it alright? He can't speak. Only nod. He bites his lip as she slips him into her and begins to rock. The pleasure is too much, and he comes too quickly. She falls forward on him, begins to laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What...what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really are a virgin. Valentin tenses a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm playing. It's fine. It's wonderful... (beat) Hold me. He does, as if he'll never release her. 48   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. MORNING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wake up, wake up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am awake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to ask you something..Say it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was wonderful. They both giggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you come to a place like this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don t follow any of the rules. Masha smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean, why does someone who doesn't follow the rules come to a place like this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ..it's not about rules.    Not for Tolstoy anyway... A knock at the door startles them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin Fedorovich. Valentin is suddenly in a panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? 49A   INT. TELYATINKI. CORRIDOR. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergeyenko hovers outside the bedroom door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the moment, I'm indisposed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, well...Leo Nikolayevich is here. He want s to see you. 49B   INT. TELYATINKI. VALENTIN'S ROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Andrey and Sofya stand together at the window, watching the joyful reunion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And into the drive to greet Chertkov. He moves immediately to her, offers her his hand and an unctuous smile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin, in bed, writes in his diary. Closing his eyes, he begins to drift off when there is a noise outside his door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Activity in the compound. Chairs on the lawn, a banner being erected, a long table being set. Preparations being made. 49   INT. TELYATINKI. VALENTIN'S ROOM. MORNING.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Light spills into Valentin's room. He lies with his arms around naked Masha.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Valentin blanches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell him... I'll be down at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes..and tell Maria Filipovna we could use another hand in the kitchen. They look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I see her I will...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you see her...yes. And if you're going to behave like rabbits, you should go live in the woods. Valentin is up, immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me go out first...give me five minutes... Masha just looks at him. 50   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at the love in him, like Jesus..suffering the children...all that... Tolstoy greets a little boy affectionately, rubs his knuckles over the boy's shaved head. A little girl approaches, takes a photograph. He bends forward to kiss her head but she pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An old man is a very ugly thing. Tolstoy sees Valentin, lights up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dear boy. Come and kiss me. Valentin, beet red, goes to him. He is warmly embraced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, who is this? Maria Filipovna. Masha comes to stand beside him. She glances at Valentin but he won't make eye contact with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're both looking so well. Life here at Telyatinki obviously agrees with you. Valentin sneezes mightily, moves a little away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God bless you, boy. What are you nervous about, now? Sit down. Sit down. Valentin takes the chair beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dear Masha, Valentin tells me you're the great treasure of Telyatinki. He claims you're a very gifted teacher. Sergeyenko lifts an eyebrow "Indeed.". Valentin is in agony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're happy to have you with us. Tolstoy notices a mosquito on Valentin's cheek. He takes the bug between his big fingers, squeezes until it pops. Chertkov watches in horror, whispers loudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean? He motions to the photographers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've killed a living thing. Chertkov hears a laugh behind him.   It is Masha who has over heard the whole thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have something to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's absurd. That's all. Chertkov is taken aback.   Valentin stares at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you saying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry but- It's a mosquito.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive him. He can't help it. He's a better Tolstoyan than I am. She can't help laughing again. Valentin sees the color rise in Chertkov's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not the message we want to send. Sasha suddenly appears. She holds a cable in her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From my mother "Nerves dreadful. Stop. Insomnia. Stop. Pulse 100. Stop. Please come home. 51   INT. TELYATINKI. CHERTKOV'S STUDY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't give in to her, Papa. It'll never end...I swear to God, that woman has an instinct for knowing when you're just about to enjoy yourself A knock on the door. Valentin opens it. It's Dushan with another cable. Tolstoy gestures for him to read it aloud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From Sofya Andreyevna. "I beg you. Stop. Unwell. Stop. Hurry back."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who taught her to use that damned machine? Valentin starts to sneeze, stifles it, starts again, stifles, starts, explodes. Guilty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps Sasha's right. Encouraging this may not be the best thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a trick, Papa. She'll drain you. You'll be miserable. Tolstoy looks from one to the other, gets up from his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, let me go with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, my dear, I'll go alone. 52   OMITTED                                                       52 53   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tolstoyan photo op. A delegation of orphans have come to pay their respects to Tolstoy. He sits in a chair beside Chertkov beneath a large banner : "Leo Tolstoy, Friend of the People.". Behind him, the disciples lay out a vegetarian feast on a plank table. Photographers and a cinematographer are strategically positioned to record the event. Each child gives Tolstoy a flower. Chertkov, in turn, hands each child a photograph of the Count giving money to the poor. Valentin enters, flushed and blushing. He pauses beside Dushan who records the scene in his diary, tears in his eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Chertkov is there. Tolstoy, Valentin and Sasha.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Close on Sofya lying in bed. She looks ravishing in the candle light. In the background, Tolstoy arrives in the bedroom door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya. A sly smile on her lips, the tension gone from her face, she seems twenty years younger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya, are you ill? She rolls toward him making it clear she's quite naked under the sheets. This is no sick bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine...now that you're home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's no good, you know, all this. You frightened everyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did I really? I don't believe it. Not you. I'm your little bird. You know the sounds I make.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was some sort of love call?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It brought you back to me. She reaches out her hand to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come out of the dark... where I can see you. He takes a step toward her, then stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? Why? Why, do you do it? We live in the country and you insist on making it an opera house. What's wrong with a little peace now and then? Sofya laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at me. This is who I am. This is what you married. We're older, maybe we're old, but I'm still your little chicken (beat) You're still my big cock. She smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me make you crow. A pause, then a huge laugh comes up from the very center of him. He twists his neck, thrusts his head upward, crows like a rooster. He virtually runs to her, embraces her, kisses her. She is a giddy girl in his arms. He breaks the embrace and begins strutting around the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me make you sing. He takes her in his arms, again, begins to kiss her neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you love me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to love me. He stops kissing her, looks her in the eye. Then, another loud crow. Laughing, they fall into each other again. 53A   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we hear their laughter over the dark old house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 54   EXT. TELYATINKI. PORCH. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not supposed to do this either. He locates the speaker by the glow of her lit cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha. You are not supposed to smoke at Telyatinki.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wouldn't look at me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was difficult in front of the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it wasn't difficult in your bed... When it was only you and me in front of God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure I was conscious of God. Masha emerges from the shadows, but keeps her distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, I made you forget God?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, only for a moment. You forgot your rules and remembered love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You make it sound very simple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is simple. What we did is what men and women do, have done, will continue doing. What could be more simple? We touched each other-- stayed close together. Something passed between us. Something real. That is a betrayal of what? Of nothing. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're afraid... All your ideas. What are you afraid of?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid I've hurt you, haven t I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I feel a little sad, but it is not for me. It's for you. She disappears into the house. Valentin looks after her. 55   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM. MORNING.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin sits by himself on the porch, writes in his diary. Down below, some of the disciples listen to peasants play music around a bonfire. A voice from the darkness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Countess wakes to find her bed empty. 56   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. BACK TERRACE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, my darling? Do you mind if I join you? Without looking up
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, my dear. He continues to write. She watches him for a long moment. She opens her diary and begins to write as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's quite insane, my darling. Everyone is making fun of you. He looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about? She continues to write.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even the muzhiks. I heard them laughing in the barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About what? Sofya looks at him knowingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughing about what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to ruin last night. She sips her tea, goes back to her writing. A pause. He follows suit. After a moment...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughing about the fact that you've developed a senile crush on a fat middle aged flatterer. Your passion for Chertkov has become a standing joke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a great affection for Vladimir Grigorivich. Let them laugh if they find it amusing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's not amusing, darling. It's sick. It's not normal. You hang on his every word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have a great deal in common.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have nothing in common. You are a genius. He's a sycophant and a pervert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because he understands what I'm trying to do? Because he tries to help me accomplish it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is using you. You just can't seem to see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is absolute nonsense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That bold, obese, idiotic man. You treat him... He turns to her...his face red with anger and frustration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's impossible for you not to distract me. Let me alone... for God's sake. You're like a spoiled child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He rises, spits on the ground, goes into the house. Sofya follows. 57    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. DINING ROOM. CONTINUOUS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She comes through the dining room to find Tolstoy on the back terrace. Wrapped in a blanket, he writes in his diary, a cup of tea in front of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Catching him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you love me, Lyovochka?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why would you betray me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because of the will? 57A   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY WAY/STAIRS/LANDING. DAY         57A Tolstoy, taken aback, says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The new will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no new will. She stares at him in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no new will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does Chertkov have it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no new will. He walks up the stairs. She follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that's why he's come back. You talk about it, you and your boyfriend. You plan for it. You have no heart for the people who really love you. You'd rather be seduced by charlatans and deluded by flatterers, all in the name of love....You can't even love your own children. You can't even love me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me where it is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no new will. 58   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. CONTINUOUS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, promise me there never will be. A moment's hesitation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ve told you the truth. Now, let me work. Please, will you? He walks to his desk. 59   OMITTED                                                      59 60   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. CONTINUOUS. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He goes to his desk, tries to ignore her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tolstoy looks up from his work. Sofya stands in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow, I'll go to the Station and lie down on the track. Tolstoy's wife becomes Anna Karenina herself! See how the papers will like that! As he goes, we hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is unbearable. You don't want a husband. You want a Greek chorus. Sofya is taken aback by his response. She walks out of the room. 61   EXT. ROAD TO TELYATINKI. DAY                                 61 Four peasants pull a water cart down a rough country road. We pan off to see Sofya in her droshky, resplendent in a white dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 62   INT. TELYATINKI. CHERTKOV'S STUDY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's here to question you about the new will. Chertkov nervous, tugs at his moustache.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How does she know it even exists?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She claims Leo Nikolayevich told her she could examine the draft.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is obviously not thinking clearly. And now we have to put up with her petty grasping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't seem petty to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg your pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He`s her life. The work, in her mind, is theirs...together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you're her advocate? You've been taken in by her celebrity. I worried about this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm talking about their history -- - simply that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should see her. Act as if nothing has happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing has happened. 63   INT. TELYATINKI. MEETING ROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya Andreyevna, at last, you honour us with your visit. Valentin watches her match him smile for smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm happy to make you happy...always. She looks at him curiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your moustache is... Drooping, one side of it anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding) It's a problem of the wax. Sofya takes them in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me get to the point. Vladimir Grigorivich, I don't wish to be your enemy. I'm delighted that my husband has a friend who understands and shares his ideals. All I want is what's reasonable - an opportunity to evaluate the new will. If you agree, I'm sure we can be friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're very kind. Sofya Andreyevna. But I can't help you. Not without specific instructions from your husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Bulgakov) Leo Nikolayevich has agreed, hasn't he Val-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No witness you produce will change my position. But I'll certainly talk to Leo Nikolayevich at the first opportunity. Sofya is livid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want us to be friends, too, Sofya. Leo Nikolayevich is the most valuable thing in the world, for both of us. We should endeavor to set things right between us. Give him peace. Let him work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (beat) Valentin Fedorovich...are you coming back to the house with me? Valentin glances between them, searching for middle ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll escort the Countess home and be back in time for supper. Sergeyenko sneers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha will be overjoyed. Valentin's nose twitches. He looks at the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you been keeping something from me? How delightful. 64   EXT. ROAD TO TELYATINKI. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've become close friends, I think. Tell me everything, dear boy. I love a romance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's nothing, really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A young woman in your life is nothing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha is a friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lover?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A good friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That sounds serious enough. Valentin looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't mean to annoy you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not annoyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You forget that I'm an experienced reader. I can read your face, every letter. It's beautifully clear. (beat) Do you love her? Valentin looks at Sofya, tears in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not something they'd understand, these so called disciples of my husband. They've never understood a word he's written. (beat) What do any of them know about love? 65   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, sorry, I'll... I didn't mean to scare you...Are you alright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine...fine...Why did you...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came back as soon as I could. It was a strange day. Leo Nikolayevich,...I love to listen to him. I love nothing more... He moves closer to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But today I could hardly concentrate. He's very close to her, now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All I could think of was you. Masha shakes her head, moves away from him. Begins to gather the pole, to refill the spilled bucket. Stops her, turns her to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I've confused you. I've confused us both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No. You didn t confuse me..I was stupid. I was afraid, but I'm not afraid anymore. Valentin wants to fight through the awkwardness. He tries to kiss her. She won't have it. She pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you, Masha!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you could help me a little. In silence, he gets the filled buckets balanced on the pole. Without another word, Masha starts toward the buildings. He doesn't know what to do. He's losing her. He shouts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha... She turns
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before the other night...I'd committed the act of copulation many times in my heart. He has her attention now, as well as that of a number of the disciples who look up from their work in the yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think about you all the time. In my heart I ve comitted the act of copulation many times. I just want to say...It was never like it was with you. Masha bursts out laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll wait for you, then. As Valentin goes to catch her up, he sees Sergeyenko watching from outside the unfinished chicken coop. 66   OMITTED                                                      66 67   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM. MORNING.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: and SERGEYENKO look through a crack in the interior window. THEIR POV - the Countess on the sofa drinking a glass of tea. Valentin enters from the meeting room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The men enter the meeting room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are back in the droshky, the return trip to Yasnaya Polyana. Valentin doesn't respond.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Masha carries two water buckets suspended from a pole across her shoulders. Arriving at a stream, she takes each bucket and fills it. It's hot work. Pausing a moment, she kneels to splash water on her face. Another P.O.V. - someone watches her from the trees. As Masha wets a cloth, puts it around her neck. Suddenly someone grabs her from behind. She screams, wrestle her way free. She turns to see Valentin, flushed, smiling, excited. He steps toward her, kicks over one of the buckets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sofya wakes up. She looks relaxed, then she sniffs, sniffs again. Out of bed, she grabs a dressing gown. Opening her door, she spots Ivan in the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ivan, who's wearing that awful perfume? Ivan a gesture indicating an elaborate moustache. She steps into the hall in time to see Tolstoy, Chertkov, Valentin and Sasha disappear into the library, ducks back into her room to avoid being seen 68   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. HALLWAY. DAY                           68 Sofya approaches the door, listens. She can make out only a few words. "Mama cannot find out", Chertkov shushing her, whispers. We push in on Sofya's anxious face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 69    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chertkov, Sasha, Dushan, Valentin and Tolstoy sit in a little clump by his desk. Tolstoy his head in his hands, looks at the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate to say it but the Countess has become more and more dangerous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not dangerous... She's concerned for the welfare of the family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we're concerned for the welfare of mankind. (to Bulgakov) Take this down. Valentin records the conversation in his diary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It s a terrible thing you ask. I can t do it. 70    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Tolstoy)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sofya, still in her dressing gown, climbs out her bedroom window onto a narrow ledge that runs along the second floor. 70A   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya stand on the window ledge high above the ground.   She begins to move toward the library balcony. 71    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been more than reasonable. She already controls the income from your property.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to him, papa. He has our best interests at heart. Tolstoy looks at Valentin, who looks at the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're speaking only of the rights to your words, your ideas. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With all love and respect, the Countess is too interested in making a profit from your work. 72   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SECOND STORY BALCONY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd)
dialogue.name: dialogue
