direction.raw_text: Sofya moves along the narrow ledge as if it's a perfectly normal activity.. Looking down, she sees a couple of gawkers watching her from the lawn. She shoos them away. 73   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's my wife. She s part of me. We've been together now, so many years.... Chertkov drives the point home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're more than a husband and father. She must understand that. The best interests of the people are one with your own. You belong to them. Valentin glances up...and is shocked to see SOFYA LOOKING IN AT THE STUDY WINDOW. She disappears. 74   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SECOND STORY BALCONY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin turns his head. Did he hear something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: SOFYA LOOKING IN AT THE STUDY WINDOW

direction.raw_text: Sofya has reached the french doors. She can hear clearly now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But she won't. She'll never understand. HER P.O.V. a crowd of gawkers gather on the lawn below her. One man sets up photographic equipment. She waves him away turns back to the window. 75   OMITTED                                                     75 76   OMITTED                                                     76 55. 77   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's unstable...I wonder if she isn't ill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It s sadly more than possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it s hard for you, papa. But we must be realistic. We pan to the french doors to see Sofya furious face as she listens to the betrayal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you really think she's fit to control the final disposition of the will? We pan back to the conspirators. Before Tolstoy can respond, Sofya charges into the room. As she does, she steps on the hem of her long dressing gown and ends up sprawled on the floor. The conspirators just stare at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How dare you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're all plotting against me. In my own house, too. I bear you thirteen children. How can you betray me like this? (beat) Someone help me up. No one moves.   Tolstoy slumps in his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give everything you've got to him, your fat little catamite. "What will it be, my dearest dear, my Vladimir Grigorivich? My wife's heart on a platter? Her kidneys? With salt? But of course, my dear Chertkov, whatever pleases you. The china. The estate. Permanent copyright on everything I've ever written? Anything for you, my love."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Her eye falls on Dushan, who very unfortunately, has chosen to take this down in his diary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me that. Give it to me, you little weasel. She grabs the offending volume. The struggle begins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Countess Sofya-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama, please... She rips the book away and after brandishing it above her head, throws it through the open doors with a guttural, rumbling growl. She turns on her tormentors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (mumbles) Can I not...Can I not have... His face is red, his body rigid with anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll kill him, Mama. That's what you want, isn't it? You want him to die!" She helps him up, takes him to his bedroom. Valentin follows. She looks at Chertkov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You! Don't think you deceive me for one little moment! I know exactly what you're doing. I want to see the will. It's my right, in the name of god.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you afraid of?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You.   I'm afraid of you. Chertkov looks at her with undisguised disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The press is bloodthirsty. Had I wished, I could've demolished you and your family. You make it easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell them anything you like. Go ahead. Ruin us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have too much respect for Leo Nikolayevich. You're lucky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why can't my husband see you for what you are? Chertkov's face is red. He starts to speak, stops. He walks to the door, then very deliberately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I had a wife like you, I would have blown my brains out long ago. (beat) Or gone to America. He leaves the room. Sofya sinks back to the floor, a flower wilting. She begins to weep. An Aria from Madame Butterfly comes over 78   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. DINING ROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you're feeling better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you like the opera?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I took singing lessons for years. I thought about a career in music. The only thing I lacked, in the end, was talent. (beat) I'm sorry about everything. She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This aria is very beautiful.. It is about a woman who is abandoned by the man who loves her...Everyone is very moved by that...in the opera. A long pause. The clink of soup spoons.   Tolstoy enters. He doesn't sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our life together has become intolerable. Stifling a sneeze, Valentin gets up to leave,tries to flee the inappropriateness of all this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down, Valentin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really, I'm expected at Telyatinki. She waves it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, no. Enjoy your dinner. We've had a disagreement. No more than any other married couple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't come for more recrimination. Despite good cause for alienation between us, I have never stopped loving you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God knows you don't make it easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why should it be easy? I'm the work of your life. You're the work of mine. Its what love is. Aside to Valentin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything with him is hysterics
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down. (beat) So, this is what love is.   Does that surprise you, boy? They both look at him
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought it might be quieter, but-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He sneezes violently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God bless you Tolstoy turns to Sofya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's right, though. If we cannot live a decent, quiet life, if I cannot work, if I cannot find some peace, I shall simply go away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go? Where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to Chertkov, but I shall go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dushan says you're killing me. Sofya rises up in cold rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then go! Go! Anywhere you please! She smashes a plate on the table to punctuate it and another and another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate you. I hate what you've become. She picks up another plate, lets it fall. Now, she acts as if she's choking or gasping for breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess...Are you alright? She fights with her collar, rips open the front of her dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shouts)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Chertkov pushes his point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From a record on the gramophone. The table is set for ten, although no one is at dinner but Sofya Andreyevna and Valentin. He is visibly uncomfortable. An awkward silence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: You'll destroy me. Dushan runs into the room. Sofya continues to tear at her clothes, stops, begins to pant, then falls to the floor in a faint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is she alright? Tolstoy tries to answer, but is overcome by a coughing fit. Dushan starts toward him but Tolstoy waves him in the direction of Sofya. He kneels beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya! Open your eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My back. My back... I'm hurting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're lying on a fork. Sit up and you'll improve markedly...Valentin, help to get her upstairs, would you? Valentin helps Sofya to her feet. Dushan gets up himself and walks to Tolstoy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's alright. I'm more concerned for you... We should all go to bed before something else happens. 79   OMITTED                                                    79 80   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was terrible there today... between them. They loved each other so much, but you see what it becomes. She stays at the sink, says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha, what s the matter? She speaks without turning to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going back to Moscow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? He gets up, goes to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chertkov spoke with me this afternoon. He says I could be more useful there...which means... Valentin shakes his head. His lip trembles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is him punishing us, punishing me for befriending Sofya Andreyevna. For not... This is Chertkov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've both disappointed him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care. You can't go away. I'll talk to him. I'll make him change his mind. i m going to make you stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I want to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm leaving the movement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can t leave Tolstoy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not. Look, when I read his Confession, it moved me, Valya. He was searching for freedom. Freedom from anger. Freedom from attachment. Freedom from all the superstition and nonsense of the church. It moved me so much. I thought that's what it would be about. Isn't that what it's about? Freedom and love? But they mix it all up. Masha reaches out and puts her arms around him. Her head falls against his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come with me. Please. Bulgakov doesn't know what to say. The silence gets more awkward as it gets longer. Slowly, she disengages herself from him,looks him in the eye. She nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to my room. As she starts away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't leave me, Masha... I need you. She turns back for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you do...I know. Then she's gone. 82   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM/HALLWAY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin sits at the bonfire, with other disciples. After a while he walks towards the house. 81   INT. TELYATINKI. KITCHEN. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's late. The house is quiet. Valentin walks into the kitchen to see Masha washing the dishes. Exhausted, he sits, stares at the floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sofya in her bed. A team of doctors hover over her. One of them peers into her eyes with a sextant-like instrument. We move into the hall to find DR. ROSSOLIMO, an expert in mental illness, conferring in the hall with Tolstoy and Dushan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe the Countess suffers from a mental degeneracy, paranoic and hysterical, chiefly the former.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. The doctor walks back into the bedroom. Tolstoy red in the face, walks away down the hall. Dushan catches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you bring him here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's an old friend, you know, from Rome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And astoundingly stupid in the way of all scientists. Dushan is wounded by his uncharacteristic lack of generosity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, my friend, but this is all very upsetting to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Tolstoy sits on a small staircase at the end of the hall. Bulgakov is already there on the step above him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take them downstairs. Thank them for me. Offer them a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin Fedorovich will stay with me, won't you, boy Valentin nods. Dushan goes to collect the doctors. MOMENTS LATER-Tolstoy goes to Sofya's bed. He takes her hand. She looks at him with all the love of a new bride. Tears come to his eyes. He kisses her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ya...your...your...I can t remember now...Yo, what did I say? What did you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You rest now. Valentin watches from the doorway as Tolstoy leaves the bedside and walks out. 83   EXT. ZASYEKA WOODS. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, I no longer feel I have a choice in the matter. She isn't... He rides forward toward the approaching Chertkov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good afternoon, Leo Nikolayevich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it? They help Tolstoy dismount. They lead him to a nearby stump and place the writing board before him. Sergeyenko hands a document to Chertkov who lays it on the board.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This will insure that the complete works will live in the public domain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monumentous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your work is the birthright of the Russian people. Now, they possess it forever. Tolstoy looks up at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need a pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. Chertkov looks at Sergeyenko who swallows hard. No pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Sergeyenko moves close to Chertkov, close enough to whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a secretary.       How can you not have a pen? Sergeyenko points at Valentin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a secretary, too.      Ask him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin Fedorovich, do you have a pen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Valentin hesitates for a moment, looks at Tolstoy, seated on the stump, staring into the middle distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do. Valentin fetches it from his satchel. Pen in hand, Tolstoy hovers over the document. A long moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel like a conspirator. Sergeyenko laughs. Chertkov glares at him. It's beyond awkward. Valentin looks to the sky, sees the crows circling again. Without further hesitation, Tolstoy picks up the pen and signs the document. Then he moves away from the group. Valentin watches him. 84   EXT. ZASYEKA WOODS. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we should get back. It'll be dark soon. May I ask you something that has nothing to do with work?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, my dear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you love your wife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your youth and your desire for happiness reminds me cruelly of my age and the impossibility of happiness for me." When I was courting Sofya, she was so young and pure, it seemed impossible that I'd ever have her. I didn't want to tell her how I felt and I wanted to tell her nothing else. So I wrote down a string of letters and asked her if she could decipher them. She looked completely confused, thinking it was a game or...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Tolstoy looks into the middle distance, remembering his love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gave her one clue. The first two Y's, I said, stand for "your youth" and then the most miraculous thing happened. She simply spoke the phrase, my phrase... Tolstoy looks at Valentin as if the boy might offer some explanation of the miraculous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...as if she had read my mind. In that moment, we both knew we would always be together. For those first years, we were incredibly happy, terrifyingly happy. His old eyes are wet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now this. Tolstoy reaches into his boot, extracts his SECRET DIARY. He takes a pen from his shirt, begins to write. Valentin is amazed. HE HAD A PEN ALL THE TIME. 85   INT. TELYATINKI. MEETING ROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you again, Valentin Fedorovich, for your forethought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a secretary, after all. Chertkov let's it go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know I had thought for a time to suggest that Leo Nikolayevich look for someone else. But...he said no. He said "He reminds me of myself when I was young." He goes. After a moment, Valentin gets up and goes to the study door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm leaving Telyatinki.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am going to Moscow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is leading you around the nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, you say the movement's about love-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... The love he tells us to practice, the love of the Gospels. Why do I have to explain this? Perfect love. Eternal love. The love that binds mankind together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I've never met mankind, only men and women, imperfect men, imperfect women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leo Nikolayevich also teaches us love can not be weakminded. Go. You won't be missed ...a naive sentimentalist Valentin looks at him for a long moment, then bursts out laughing, walks away
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you laughing? You think I'm ridiculous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm laughing because I didn't sneeze. 86   OMITTED                                                    86 87   OMITTED                                                    87 88   OMITTED                                                    88 68. 89   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. TOLSTOY STUDY/BEDROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is an autumn afternoon. Valentin and Tolstoy pick their way through the thick undergrowth. As they come into a clearing. Valentin is surprised to see a portable table and several chairs set up like lawyers office in the middle of the wood. Sergeyenko fiddles with a piece of paper on the desk. Chertkov comes toward them. Tolstoy stops his horse. He turns to Valentin with tears in his eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin and Tolstoy water their horses at a stream. Tolstoy seems weary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.ToD: HE HAD A PEN ALL THE TIME
result.heading: HE HAD A PEN ALL THE TIME

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin exhausted, sits at the long table.   Chertkov appears at his office door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tolstoy has fallen asleep at his desk, his SECRET DIARY open before him. Sofya enters without knocking. He bolts up groggily, tries to hide the little book. Sofya, meanwhile, holds up the letter in her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lyovochka? Prozeveskeny wants to purchase the rights to your work after your death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I shall try and die as soon as is convenient.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be silly. They've offered one million rubles. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you not be pleased?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't write for publishers. I write for people. He gets up from his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin's in the library.    He's asked to speak to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Splendid...while your wretched family is left to starve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't see anyone starving in this house. On the contrary, our privilege revolts me. He goes.   She calls after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're always first to the trough...always have been. Sofya sinks into his chair. On the desk is the photograph of herself and Tolstoy that we saw her hang on the wall in the early part of the film. She looks at the wall. There in it's place is the offending photograph of CHERTKOV that she had removed earlier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She can fix that. But as she picks up the photo of her and her husband, she notices A SMALL VOLUME, THE SECRET DIARY, lying under it. She begins to read. 90   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, dear boy? You look unhappy. What do you want to say? But before Valentin can respond A GUNSHOT RINGS OUT. 91   OMITTED                                                       91 92   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. TOLSTOY BEDROOM/STUDY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin waits on the sofa.   Tolstoy walks in, goes to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sofya sits in a chair, firing shot after shot at the photograph of Chertkov. Tolstoy and Valentin enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya, what are you doing? She turns toward him, waves the gun in his direction. Valentin ducks against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could you do this to me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You hurt me again and again. You take little pieces of me until I become nothing. I don't know who I am anymore. (beat) I read your diary. I know what you've done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You behave like this, I have no choice. Now give me the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Give me the gun!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give it to me, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sofya throws the gun at her husband. She runs out of the room. We see the shattered photograph of Chertkov. After a moment, Tolstoy into his chair.   Valentin watches him in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like you to stay here tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, of course. With that, the old man gets up and leaves the room, leaving Valentin in the wreckage of his world. 93   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin. Valentin. He is immediately awake. Sasha, lamp in hand, crouches beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get up. He's leaving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He s leaving. 95   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. TOLSTOY'S BEDROOM/STUDY. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The wind blows the trees around the old house.   We see a lighted lamp move up the stairs. 94   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. NIGHT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Valentin in his makeshift bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bags are being prepared. Sasha is packing clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Essentials only. Nothing that isn't absolutely necessary. Valentin struggles to close a case full of books and papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please...we must hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where will you go? No one responds. Dushan comes to Tolstoy, sits down and begins the ritual taking of the pulse. Meanwhile, Sasha wraps a heavy fur coat around his shoulders. She smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely essential.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lantern, I think. It's very dark tonight. (beat) And the apparatus for giving an enema. 96   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything's ready. Dushan climbs into the carriage. Tolstoy turns abruptly and walks back toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's changed his mind. He's going back to the house. They watch as Tolstoy kneels on the wet grass, bending low to rub his hands against the earth. After a moment, Valentin goes to him, kneels next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want to go back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I was a boy, my brother Nikolai once brought me to a place when I was a boy. He told me he'd found a green stick with some words on it... the secret to happiness for all men everywhere. He hid it in the ground. I looked for it very often. I've looked for it all these years. I really believed I would find it here...but I never did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Tolstoy looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never did...but this life is behind me now. He kisses the ground of his beloved home, gets up and they walk back to the droshky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Help me up, will you? As they go, he hands Valentin an envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give this to Sofya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will. They reach the carriage. Sasha embraces him, kisses him over and over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be well. Be well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't cry. I'll send for you when I can. They help him up onto the droshky and the carriage starts slowly away from the old house. 97   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. MORNING                       97 Out in front of the house, an old peasant woman pulls the feathers off a chicken. Over her impassive face, we hear deep, heavy sobs. 98   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SITTING ROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm simply telling you what happened. He's gone. I have no idea where. Nobody does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a liar. (beat) Liar! Sasha won't rise to the bait. Valentin comes into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, he's gone. (to Bulgakov) For good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so, yes. There is a pause. Sofya suddenly smiles, becomes solicitous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling Sasha, where is your father? I know you know. Please, please. Don't play games with me. Now it s not the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honestly, I have no idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have this for you. It is a letter. She grabs it, as if it is something that might feed a terrible hunger at the center of her. Moving into a corner, she tears it open and begins to read. They both watch Sofya's passion. Her face quivers, the muscles in her neck stand out. Her shoulders begin to shake. Crumbling the paper in her hand, she twists her head and screams. Then, gathering up her dress, she runs out the door. Sasha move immediately to the window. From her P.O.V., we see Sofya streaking across the lawn. They look at each other
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pond! They run out. 99   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sasha suddenly steams past him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama, Mama! Stop. Not this. Hurry! Hurry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess! 100   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. POND. DAY                             100 Sofya has reached the bathhouse. Peasant women watch her as they do their wash. She glances back her pursuers, races on. Tiring now, she goes to her knees. She crawls along the jetty toward the water. At the edge of the jetty, she falls on her back then turns over, most ungracefully, and rolls off sideways into the pond. HIGH ANGLE. Sofya sinks into the black water. The sound of her rescuers fades away and is replaced by Tolstoy's voice, reading the farewell note she still clutches in her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My position in the house has become intolerable. What I'm doing now is what people have commonly done - leave their worldly life behind to spend their last days in peace and solitude. SLOW MOTION She floats, strangely relaxed, beneath the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg you to forgive me for everything I've done to you, just as I forgive you with all my soul for everything you've done to me. The silence is suddenly ripped apart by the rescuers. Sasha and Valentin jumping into the pond. Sasha, barely able to swim herself, thrashes in the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sasha, go back to the jetty. Here, let me help you. He offers his arm, using it to push her to safety.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! She's drowning.     Help her!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will. I will. Stay here. With that, he pushes away from the dock and makes a sharp plunge under the water. Sasha watches, waits...and after a long moment Valentin surfaces pulling Sofya with him. On the dock, the servants and Sasha help him to get her heavy body , water soaked dress, back onto the bank. She looks terrible. Her tongue lolling out, water drizzling from her open mouth. Sasha is overcome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's dead. My mother. She's dead. Ivan takes action. He rolls her on to her stomach, works to expel water from her lungs. This goes on for an agonizing length of time. Valentin looks to the sky... dull and gray. Then a sound, coughing sputtering. She is alive. Sasha, Valentin, and the servants help up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me take you to the house, mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me die. Please. Why would you rob me of that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go to the house. Sofya is suddenly clear, almost calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ivan, go to the station. Find out which train the master took. Ivan looks at Sasha for approval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see no harm in it. Let's get her to bed. Valentin nods. Ivan appears beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Life returns to torture her for awhile. He laughs out loud,then walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 101   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. DINING ROOM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sasha walks into dining room. Valentin pours them tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's exhausted herself. She's slept for nearly four hours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad she can sleep. The pain subsides a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The noise subsides a little. They smile at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, a little. Ivan comes down the stairs. He stops in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A message, miss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, for your father. From the Countess, miss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's allowed to send a note to my father. I just don't know where to tell her to send it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's addressed it to train number 9. That's the train the master took. The station master told me...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you giving it to me? She is allowed to send my father a note! Ivan steps forward and hands her the note to inspect. Sasha can't help but laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She never gives up. (reading the note) "Dearest papa. Return at once. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sasha." She signed it with my name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ingenious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Obvious. She pockets the note. Ivan continues to stand there. Sasha looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gave me this as well...the stationmaster. A note for you. Sasha opens it, reads. She looks up, flushed with excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's with my aunt.      At the Shamardino. Sasha runs out of the room. 102   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY                          102 Sasha, on horse back, rides up and by the camera and away down the alley of trees that lead away from the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've all gone 103   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sitting at his desk, Valentin looks up to see Sofya standing in the doorway. She looks exhausted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here. She walks to his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're writing to your girl. That's lovely. Sofya touches his shoulder with real affection, then walks across the room to her husband's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know if she's my girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you believe you'll see her again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I very much hope so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Refuse to believe in the end of love. Do all you can to prevent it... Sofya picks up a photograph of the two of them, examines it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you know where he is, Valentin. Valentin hesitates. She walks back to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't ask you to betray his trust...but I need you to go to him. I do. I have to see him. I have to talk to him. I won't make a scene. Promise him that. I must see him. 103A   OMITTED                                                    103A 104    OMITTED                                                    104 105    OMITTED                                                    105 106    OMITTED                                                    106 107    OMITTED                                                    107 108    EXT. COUNTRYSIDE. DAWN                                     108 Clouds of steam against the white sky. A great black train travels through the bleak world 109    INT. THIRD CLASS CARRIAGE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tolstoy rests on the hard bench of the third class carriage he always insists on. He writes on his lapboard. We pan to an adjacent bench to find VALENTIN, now with them. He and Sasha have a map spread out in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's right, you know, to go. She will be right behind us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ve told you she has promised she wouldn t make any problems. But besides, where are we going? Tolstoy has overheard them.

dialogue.raw_text: Sofya is in a rage. Sasha sits nearby.

dialogue.raw_text: Sofya sprints away from the house and into the trees. A couple of servants join the chase, Ivan and VANYA, a fat manservant. Valentin, head of the group, sees Sofya move out of the birches. She's heading straight to the pond.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd)

direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He will be fine. 114   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY                                 114 The train pulls into a small, dusty station, ASTAPOVO. Valentin and Dushan support, help him off the train.   Sasha looks at the sad, empty platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've come to the end of the world. 115   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be comfortable here, papa. The rest of us...we'll find cots or sleep in the station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then we'll be on our way. 116   OMITTED                                                      116 117   OMITTED                                                      117 118   INT. ASTAPOVO. TELEGRAPH OFFICE. NIGHT.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 119   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. NIGHT                        119 A message comes over the cable machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tolstoy ill at Astapovo. Temperature high. Send it to Sofya Andreyevna, Yasnaya Polyana. 120   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SITTING ROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya paces. Andrey lolls on the couch reading the paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We must leave at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll make inquiries in the morning, mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll rent a train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That'll cost a fortune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't say irrelevant things, Andrey. It's unbecoming. Contact someone. I'll go and pack.

direction.raw_text: Press and various hangers on have begun to arrive at Astapovo. Outside the station master's house, Dushan gives an update, temperature, pulse. Valentin emerges from the telegraph office, telegrams and cables in his hands. A long passenger train pulls in from the north. There's general commotion at the new arrival. "The Countess." "Is it the Countess?"... More press, a cinematographer lugging his gear and CHERTKOV. He spots Valentin. There is no greeting, no embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bulgakov! Where is he?    Take me to him. As they make their way across the tracks, Chertkov can barely contain his glee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He left...astonishing...He actually, finally left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wasn't well enough to travel. It's very cold. Chertkov doesn't hear, He's basking in his victory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a triumph for the movement. 122   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin leads Chertkov through the door. Chertkov stops short, whispers
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks so small. Now, Tolstoy sees him, wakes up, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's(hic)you. The men embrace. Tears roll down the both men's cheeks. Tolstoy continues to hiccup throughout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dear friend, waht is all of this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I needed (hic) to see you. Thank you. We have so much (hic) to do. (hic) I m sorry. Damn hic ups. (beat) Have you seen Sofya?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've made a point not to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know when (hic) she'll come. But she'll come (hic). I know it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we'll be ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready for what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Chertkov doesn't respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, but it's time for your enema.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't apologize, my friend. Your enemas(hic)have become the news of the world. (smiles) Now, all of you, help turn me over. 123   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone is asleep. Valentin keeps a vigil at Tolstoy's bedside. His rest is fitful, his breathing ragged. Valentin stands and walks out. 124   INT. ASTAPOVO. TELEGRAPH OFFICE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin approaches the little window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to send another cable. The man nods, readies his pencil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At Astapovo. Stop. Tolstoy Ill. Stop. Heart breaking. Stop. Please Come.... That's it. The man looks to him for an address.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It goes to Masha...to Maria Filipovna Melinov, Moscow. Thank you. 125   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The media circus is in town. There are snack bars and huts, an army camp with typewriters instead of guns. Several news cameras are set up near the stationmaster's house. Tents have been erected as make shift shelters and offices. Reporters struggle to get into the telegraph office. Word goes around something big is happening. At the platform, we see the highly polished private train pull in. The Countess has arrived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SOFYA APPEARS in her handsome traveling clothes. An unctuous little orthodox priest follows her out of the train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the Count should have a change of heart...if in the last moment he chooses to confess, mother church is there to embrace him with open arms. She nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll see what I can do, father. She moves with purpose across the tracks and through the throng Reporters pelt her with questions. 126   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chertkov, Sasha and Valentin watch through the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's coming this way. Chertkov starts to put on his coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not before she stops to tell them lies, catalogue my atrocities.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me speak to her. He heads toward the door. 127   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY                               127 Sofya has reached the edge of the platform where DUSHAN gives his medical update, temperature and pulse, to the press. She pulls Dushan aside. Reporters surround them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to see my husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes I'll...uhm...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to see him. Now! Dushan is terrified. Valentin arrives at the platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin...Will you help me?    I have to see him. Please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. But I'm not certain if it s the best time, Countess. She starts toward the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is.   It's the right time for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya Andreyevna... (to the crowd) Stay back, stay back. 128   EXT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. DAY                    128 As Valentin arrives outside the door, he see Sofya physically recoil. She is confronted by Chertkov and Sasha blocking the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to see my husband. Members of the press, crowd `round trying to listen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's too weak now, mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he's not too weak to see you. Not too weak to see that... She gestures in Chertkov's direction. The passion attracts more onlookers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you really want to do this here? She does her best to ignore him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am the leper outside the gate, while he sleeps with the devil himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vladimir Gregorovich is here because father asked him to be here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . This stops Sofya for a moment. She looks to Valentin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that true? Valentin nods.   She tries another tack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you told him I nearly drowned in the pond?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We didn't have to. It was in all the papers. Valentin is very aware of the publicness of it all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me take you back. But she plows on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did he say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That if you killed yourself, he'd be upset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd be upset?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Horribly upset...but he could not have acted other than he did. Sofya begins to sob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to see him. (beat) He's not your husband.   He's my husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're unbearable. Sasha goes back toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you are a stone-hearted bitch of a daughter. Sasha disappears back inside. Sofya screams after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I lost five children. Why couldn't one of them have been you? Chertkov watches, makes little attempt to conceal his pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you finished? A pause. Sofya is suddenly aware of the crowd around her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin, will you take me back? Valentin nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, of course. Sofya takes his arm, starts back across the platform. Shaken, she tries her best to maintain her dignity as she walks through the crowd. She leans against Valentin, whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've behaved badly, haven't I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Countess, Don't worry. Not at all. Around her, journalists ask questions, photographers call out "Turn to us, Countess." "Show us your eyes." 129   OMITTED                                                       129 130   INT. ASTAPOVO. PRIVATE TRAIN. DAWN.

direction.raw_text: Valentin comes into the room, acknowledges Chertkov who sits at his makeshift desk going through letters and cables. He goes to the bedside, stops next to Dushan. Silence, interrupted only by Tolstoy's incessant hiccups. Valentin notices Dushan is on the verge of tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? Dushan, what s wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to him. I'm supposed to be a doctor, for God's sake. Weak, feverish, Tolstoy sits up in bed.   Sasha moves to help him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? What is it? Valentin goes to Tolstoy. He's in a kind of panic. Chertkov comes into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's come, hasn't she? She`s here. He points to the corner.   But it is nothing, a gray shape thrown by a coat rack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're imagining things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's true, Leo Nikolayevich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sasha...where's your mother? Tolstoy's eyes fill with tears. Valentin looks to Sasha. She looks from him to Chertkov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's at home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If she wanted to see me I couldn't refuse her. (beat) Is she going to come here? All eyes are on Sasha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so...I don't know, Papa. There's no way to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To what? Will she waiver?    A long, agonizing beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's at home. I'm sure of it. Valentin looks at the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Papa. Tolstoy nods, pats Sasha's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very beautiful isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our home?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. He leans back against the pillow and drifts again. Sasha gets up and goes outside. After a moment, Valentin follows. 135   EXT. ASTAPOVO. STATION MASTER'S HOUSE. DAY                   135 Valentin sees her leaning against the wall.   She's in pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He said to me once..."you're like your mother. You're so full of anger." She turns to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's terrible...but who will protect him? I don't want him to die. Valentin touches her face, goes back inside and into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 136   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATION MASTER'S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. DAY. 136 Where Chertkov has made a makeshift office. He pores through the cables, letters and telegrams that litter the station master's dining table. He holds one up for Valentin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kind thoughts from George Bernard Shaw. Valentin walks to the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You lied to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep your voice down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wants to see her.    You heard him say it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What exactly do you think she will bring him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don t know, they ve been married for 48 years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ll tell you what she ll bring...Vanity, fuss and noise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She promised me-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Promised you what? You ve seen her at close quarters, boy. You think she s capable of restraining herself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have a whole life togehter. Why do you have to deny that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a victim of her romantic nonsense. You seem to forget she wants to destroy everything we do. She travels with that unctious little priest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep the priest away-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These people are vultures. They send in at the last moment and welcome him back to the church. That's their fantasy. (beat) A death bed recantation. Do you have any idea the damage it would do? Everything he's dreamed of, everything we've worked for will be gone. A simple noble death is what we want. It is what he wants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you want an icon. You want to take photographs and give out postcards..You want people to kneel in front of an image you ve created. But he doesn t wanted that. He never wanted that, and it will give him no peace. (beat) He wants to see her...let her come. They see Sasha looking from the door.   She turns and closes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will do everything in my power to prevent that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God. You exhaust me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to think you were just naive, Valentin, maybe a little stupid.   I see now you're more dangerous than she is. He turns back at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me one thing. That image you want to create, just looks like you, doesn t it? Valentin leaves the room. 137   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The circus sleeps. Valentin sits on a bench outside the station master's house. The tents erected by the press glow like lanterns in the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Some people lie on the hard platform. He looks across the tracks at Sofya's private car. A single light burns in the window 138   INT. ASTAPOVO. PRIVATE TRAIN CARRIAGE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya keeps her solitary vigil. The priest has fallen asleep sitting up. She finishes her prayers, gets up, looks across at the lonely cottage. She can make out Valentin's figure on the platform. 139   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM.NIGHT
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dushan appears in the doorway. Solemn, he gestures for him to come inside. Valentin stands. 140   INT. ASTAPOVO. PRIVATE TRAIN CARRIAGE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya watches the two figures disappear inside. 141   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin sees Chertkov standing near the bed. Dushan returns to the chair next to Tolstoy. His cheeks are damp, his breathing irregular.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It can't be right.    His fever is down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His pulse, you see... Dushan begins to cry. Suddenly, Tolstoy becomes lucid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya...my dear Sofya. So much has (hic) fallen to her. Everyone moves nearer the bed. Tolstoy looks at Valentin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's going to look after her? (beat) Someone needs to look after her. There is a long pause. Sasha looks at Valentin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall I call her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is it(hic). The end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He seems to smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want to see her, papa?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sasha, Sasha.. It's(hic)nothing...Nothing. He falls onto his pillow, asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's almost over. Sasha looks at him, shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't do this anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won t know who she is anyway. 142   INT. ASTAPOVO. TRAIN CARRIAGE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone sleeps but Sofya. There is a knock on the door. Sofya opens it. It is Sasha. A pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Has he asked for me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to come.    Take a coat. It's cold. 143   EXT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya and Sasha walk to the door. The reporter calls out
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess...Countess...Do you have any information? Countess...Is he dying? Is he dead? Sasha takes her mother's hand. 144   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She steps into the room. For a moment, she seems overwhelmed at the sight of him. She looks at Valentin, who nods at her as if to say go on. Sofya walks past Chertkov without acknowledging him. Dushan lets go his hold of Tolstoy's wrist and gets out of the chair, out of her way. She approaches her sleeping, husband, the love of her life, her cross, her everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lyovochka! There is no response.    She throws her arms around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please forgive me, my darling!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a fool.. I'm a selfish woman. But I love you. Please believe me. Please understand me. Please forgive me for all my weakness and badness. Please! Please! Love me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother! Sasha takes her hand, whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Control yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was I shouting?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to control yourself. Sofya looks around and sits back. Strangely, she does control herself. She becomes very still. She takes her husband's hand, begins quietly to speak to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't speak, but I hear you. She carries on two sides of an impossible conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Do you love me, Lyovochka." (beat) "Never stopped, my little bird." (beat) "And you will never stop" (beat) "Never." (beat) "Nor ever leave me again." (beat) "Never, ever again. (beat) "Good...good... let's go home"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She sits very still holding her husband's hand. Then, it seems she feels the slightest of movements, the slightest squeeze of her hand. She looks down to see Tolstoy open his eyes. He looks at her for a moment, the hint of a smile, then closes his eyes again. Valentin sees it, glances at Sasha.   Then, he begins to fight for breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First cessation. A general sense of panic at the proximity of death. Tolstoy fights for a last breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Second cessation. Sofya whispers quietly to her dying husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please forgive me if I cry a little now. Tolstoy continues to struggle, then silence, silence. Sasha starts to sob. Sofya reaches out to her daughter. Sasha comes to her mother who holds her. She feels someone next to her.   She looks up. It's Chertkov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am sorry, Sofya Andreyevna. The most unlikely thing, she pats his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's alright. What happens from now on... it will never really matter. Not really. Everything's finished. Chertkov sits beside them. She turns to Dushan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dushan, could you tell them your great friend is gone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. He nods, walk out into the dawn light to tell the world Leo Tolstoy is dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 145   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY                                  145 A sizeable crowd has assembled, the usual reporters, photographers, cinematographers, but students, too, and soldiers, factory workers, housewives. Dushan faces the crowd. Quiet. Quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At ten minutes after six in the morning, a great soul passed from our world. Leo Nikoleyevich Tolstoy is dead. As Dushan finishes his tribute, a single voice begins to sing the old Russian hymn, Eternal Memory. Gradually, more and more of the crowd picks it up. Valentin begins to sing. His eyes run over the crowd of mourners. Then, something stops the flow of his gaze. His eyes fill with tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha... Masha. She walks slowly toward him out of the crowd. He goes to her, takes her in a long embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha...Masha...I'm so sorry he's gone. He s gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Yes. I know, but I came for you, Valya. I came for you, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you. I do. I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, hold me. Hold me. Hold me. The song, the voices swell around them.   They hold each other like they will never let go. 146   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A black draped funeral train waits in the station. Many mourners are congregated on the platform. Chertkov comes out of the little house, followed by Andrey, Valentin and Dushan carrying Tolstoy's coffin to the train. Sofya appears with Sasha, who escorts her through the crowd. The Orthodox priest approaches .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a daughter of the church, I'm sure you wouldn't object to my saying a few words at the funeral. Sofya stares at him for a long moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My husband needs no justification. Besides, it s been enough talking as it is. Thank you, father. She climbs onto the train. 147   INT. ASTAPOVO. PRIVATE CARRIAGE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sofya settles into the comfort of the private car. She sits next to Sasha. Andrey and Dushan are near her. There's a noise from outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Countess...Countess. She looks out. Below the train window, Valentin and Masha stand hand in hand. She gets up and opens the window. 148   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, Countess. This may not be the time, but- Sofya smiles
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valentin... and who's this...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masha...this is Masha. Sofya nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is your girl. Good. Good. Is there anything I can do for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no. Not at all. I just wanted to say good bye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes...Good bye, good bye.     God bless you.
direction.name: direction
